Adviserate, October 26, 1946. rj/ie> • © His Highness has asked me to send to you the enclosed letter from one of the Shaikhs on the Persian coast with whom the Khalifah have a long time been on very friendly terms. I enclose a translation of the letter. The bearer of the letter explained to His Highness that what Shaikh Yasr really wants is to obtain British Nationality. Will you please advise me on what lines His Highness should reply ? Captain H.D.H. Ranee, H. B. M’s political Agent, Bahrain. Confidential. BAHRAIN RECEIPT.Translation of letter dated 15th Dulqaada 1365 (October 10, 1946) from Shaikh Yasr bin Mathkoor Nasuri, to H.H. Shaikh Sulman bin Hamad AlKhalifah, Bahrain. After salaams and respects: First we pray for your health and happiness which are foremost in our mind; we also pray that God may grant you whatever you wish for. May God protect you from all evil. We wish to inform you about what we had in mind because you are in the place of a father for us and we sons. We find that circumstances have changed, so are our internal affairs. The country is in a state of confusion. Everyone does as he pleases. We now find that we should ask your advice and consult you about our afrairs. Wb have therefore sent our messenger to you, Mir Abdulla bin Mir Ahmad. He will explain every thing to you. When you understand what we have in our mind, we request you to help us in whatever way you can with those who represent the Brit ish Government, May God preserve their prestige and glory, so that they may extend their guardianship over usand help us. It behoves you to help us during these days in whichever way you think best and suitable. Our object is ties of friend ship with your friends. Whatever we wished to be conveyed to you we have explained to our messenger who will explain to you in detail. Today we have no one in the island of Bahrain except God and yourself. We are sure that what you wish for yourself you will wish for us. This is what was to have been said. We expect to receive your letters containing your instructions. May God preserve you. Sd/- Yasr bin Mathkoor Nasuri. S.ZD.O. No.C/1256 The 11th November, *46 Dear Belgrave, £| Please refer to your demi-official letter No.2270-9A dated the 26th October, 1946. 2. I am returning the enclosure to your letter. The writer of it should be advised to apply to the nearest British Consulate in Persia for any assistance which he may require. D. Belgrave, Esq., C.B.E., Adviser to the Bahrain Government, Bahrain.

titleInfo.title: 'File 29/4 Application for British Nationality by Persian Shaikhs'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 7; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file contains a translation of a letter in which Shaikh Yasr bin Mathkoor Nasuri requests assistance from Shaikh Salmān bin Ḥamad Āl Khalīfah, the Ruler of Bahrain.The file also contains a letter from Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, to Captain Hugh Dunstan Rance, Political Agent in Bahrain that states the reason behind the Shaikh Yasr's letter was his ultimate desire to obtain British nationality.
